B virus.facts:
Here are the key facts about B virus:

• B virus is a Simplexvirus that naturally infects macaque monkeys and is similar to Herpes simplex virus 1

• When transmitted to humans, it can cause severe encephalitis with an 80% fatality rate if untreated

• The virus was first identified in 1932 after the death of William Brebner, a physician infected while researching polio

• Transmission to humans typically occurs through monkey bites, scratches, or exposure to mucous membranes

• Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for human survival

• By 2002, approximately 50 human cases had been documented, with 26 well-documented cases

• The mortality rate decreased between 1987-2004 due to improved treatment and diagnosis

• Recent notable cases include deaths of a researcher at Yerkes Research Center (1997) and a veterinarian in China (2021)

• Personal protective equipment is essential when working with macaques, especially those testing positive for the virus
B virus.title: B virus

Heavy metal hyperaccumulation.facts:
Here are the key facts about Heavy metal hyperaccumulation from the article:

• Phytoremediation uses living plants to clean up soil, air, and water contaminated with hazardous materials, combining proper soil amendments and agronomic techniques

• The process relies on certain plants called "hyperaccumulators" that can bioaccumulate chemicals from the environment and detoxify various compounds

• While toxic heavy metals cannot be degraded through phytoremediation, organic pollutants can be broken down, making them primary targets for this treatment

• The technology has been successfully used to treat soils contaminated with metals like cadmium, lead, aluminum, arsenic, and antimony

• Specific plants proven effective for hyperaccumulation include mustard plants, alpine pennycress, hemp, and pigweed

• Phytoremediation has been successfully implemented in restoring abandoned metal mines and treating sites contaminated with polychlorinated biphenyls

• The ability to accumulate pollutants varies significantly between plant species and even between cultivars within the same species

• Phytoremediation is generally more cost-effective than traditional soil remediation methods, though it hasn't yet been demonstrated to solve major environmental challenges
Heavy metal hyperaccumulation.title: Phytoremediation

Heavy metals.facts: No facts available for Heavy metals
Heavy metals.title: Heavy metals

Human parainfluenza viruses.facts:
Here are the key facts about Human parainfluenza viruses (HPIVs):

• HPIVs are a group of four distinct single-stranded RNA viruses belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family that cause human parainfluenza

• They are the second leading cause of respiratory hospitalizations in children under 5 years of age, after respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

• HPIV virions are 150-250 nm in size and contain negative sense RNA with a genome of approximately 15,000 nucleotides

• The viruses can be detected through three main methods: cell culture, immunofluorescent microscopy, and PCR

• HPIVs are classified into two genera: Respirovirus (HPIV-1 & HPIV-3) and Rubulavirus (HPIV-2 & HPIV-4)

• The viruses follow the "rule of six" - the most efficient HPIVs have a genome nucleotide total divisible by 6

• Viral entry and replication occurs through attachment and fusion between the virus and host cell membrane, involving key proteins like hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) and fusion (F) protein

• The viruses contain six key structural proteins and follow a specific structural gene sequence: 3′-NP-P-M-F-HN-L-5′
Human parainfluenza viruses.title: Human parainfluenza viruses

Human virome.facts:
Here are the key facts about the Human virome:

• The human virome is the complete collection of all viruses found in and on the human body, including those that infect human cells and bacteria

• Every person has a unique virome that is influenced by factors such as lifestyle, age, geographic location, and seasonal changes

• Viruses in the human virome can be either disease-causing or asymptomatic, and some become permanently integrated into the human genome

• The exact number of viral particles in a healthy human adult is unknown, but in nature, viruses typically outnumber bacteria by a ratio of 10:1

• The human virome is constantly evolving due to the rapid evolution rate of viruses

• Deep sequencing is a key modern method for studying the virome, allowing researchers to identify new viruses without needing to grow them in culture

• In 2024, scientists discovered "obelisks" (a new class of viroid-like elements) and "oblins" (their related proteins) in the human microbiome

• Understanding the human virome is considered important for comprehending how microbes affect human health and disease
Human virome.title: Human virome

Hyperaccumulator.facts:
Here are the key facts about Hyperaccumulators:

• Hyperaccumulators are plants that can grow in metal-rich soils and concentrate extremely high levels of metals in their tissues at concentrations that would be toxic to related species

• These plants extract metals from soil at higher rates than non-hyperaccumulating species and can transfer metals more quickly from roots to shoots

• The ability to hyperaccumulate metals is due to differential gene expression and regulation, rather than different genes between related species

• Hyperaccumulators have potential practical applications in:
  - Phytoremediation (cleaning contaminated soils)
  - Phytomining (extracting valuable metals from soil)

• Unlike normal plants, hyperaccumulators concentrate more metals in their leaves and shoots than in their roots, showing an unusual shoot-to-root metal concentration ratio

• The evolutionary advantage of metal hyperaccumulation may be protection against herbivores, either through direct toxicity or by enhancing other defensive compounds

• Some hyperaccumulators, like Thlaspi caerulescens, can accumulate metals (such as zinc) at concentrations 24-60 times higher than non-accumulator plants
Hyperaccumulator.title: Hyperaccumulator

Jo Marie Payton-France.facts:
Here are the key facts about Jo Marie Payton:

• Born on August 3, 1950, in Albany, Georgia, and later moved to Opa-locka, Florida during her teens

• Graduated from Miami Carol City Senior High School (1968) and Albany State University

• Best known for portraying Harriette Winslow on both Perfect Strangers (1987) and Family Matters (1989-1998)

• Left Family Matters in December 1997 due to tensions with co-star Jaleel White, before the show's final season ended

• Voiced Suga Mama Proud in The Proud Family animated series (2001-2005) and its subsequent movie and revival series

• Received an NAACP Image Award nomination in 2005 for her role in The Proud Family

• Had a recurring role on Will & Grace (1999-2000) as Ben Doucette's personal assistant

• Has appeared in numerous other TV shows including Desperate Housewives, Reba, Girlfriends, and 227

These facts capture her most significant career achievements and biographical details while remaining concise and verifiable from the source material.
Jo Marie Payton-France.title: Jo Marie Payton

Paramyxoviridae.facts:
Here are the key facts about Paramyxoviridae:

• Paramyxoviridae is a family of negative-strand RNA viruses that primarily infects vertebrates and causes diseases including measles, mumps, and respiratory tract infections

• The virus particles (virions) are enveloped, spherical or pleomorphic, with a diameter of approximately 150 nm

• The viral genome is non-segmented, negative-sense RNA that is 15-19 kilobases in length and contains 6-10 genes

• The virus structure includes fusion proteins and attachment proteins that appear as spikes on the surface, with matrix proteins inside the envelope for stabilization

• The genome has a specific organization with a 3' leader sequence (50 nucleotides) that acts as a transcriptional promoter and a 5' trailer sequence (50-161 nucleotides)

• Gene transcription follows a gradient due to "transcriptional polarity" - genes closer to the 3' end are transcribed more frequently than those near the 5' end

• The family is organized into nine subfamilies containing 23 genera

These facts capture the essential characteristics of the virus family's structure, genome organization, and basic properties.
Paramyxoviridae.title: Paramyxoviridae

Poxvirus gene expression.facts:
Here are the key facts about Poxvirus gene expression:

• Poxviridae is a family of double-stranded DNA viruses that infects vertebrates and arthropods, divided into two subfamilies: Chordopoxvirinae (vertebrate-infecting) and Entomopoxvirinae (insect-infecting)

• Four genera of poxviruses can infect humans: Orthopoxvirus (including smallpox), Parapoxvirus, Yatapoxvirus, and Molluscipoxvirus

• The most common poxvirus infections in humans are vaccinia (prevalent in Indian subcontinent) and molluscum contagiosum, with Mpox infections increasing in West and Central Africa

• Smallpox has a long documented history, with one of the earliest suspected cases being Egyptian pharaoh Ramses V (circa 1150 BCE)

• Smallpox caused devastating epidemics, including the death of 3.2 million Aztecs within two years of its introduction to the Americas in the 16th century

• The disease was officially declared eradicated by WHO in 1979, with the last endemic case occurring in Somalia in 1977

• After eradication, all smallpox virus samples were restricted to two WHO reference labs: CDC in Atlanta, USA and the Institute of Virus Preparations in Moscow

• Despite sharing a similar name, chickenpox is not a true poxvirus but is caused by the herpesvirus varicella zoster
Poxvirus gene expression.title: Poxviridae

Toxic heavy metal.facts:
Here are the key facts about toxic heavy metals:

• The term "toxic heavy metal" is considered misleading by scientists, as not all heavy metals are toxic and some toxic metals are not heavy

• Major toxic elements include cadmium, mercury, and lead, which are on the WHO's list of 10 chemicals of major public concern

• Toxic metals can enter living organisms through inhalation, diet, and manual handling, where they interfere with vital cellular functions

• Some metals that are toxic in high doses are actually essential for human health in small quantities, including copper, iron, zinc, and selenium

• Common sources of toxic metal contamination include fertilizers, aging water infrastructure, microplastics, and industrial activities

• The toxicity of arsenic, mercury, and lead has been known since ancient times, but systematic scientific studies began around 1868

• Heavy metal poisoning in humans is typically treated using chelating agents

• The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) has officially rejected the term "heavy metals" as meaningless and misleading

• Toxic metals occur naturally in the earth but become concentrated through human activities and certain geochemical processes
Toxic heavy metal.title: Toxic heavy metal

Vaccinia.facts:
Here are the key facts about Vaccinium:

• Vaccinium is a genus of shrubs in the heath family (Ericaceae) that includes commercially important berries like cranberries, blueberries, bilberries, and lingonberries

• The plants grow exclusively in acidic soils and commonly form mycorrhizal relationships with fungi to help access nutrients

• Plant size varies from ground-trailing varieties to shrubs reaching 1-2 meters tall, with some tropical species growing as epiphytes

• The genus contains approximately 450 species, found primarily in cool regions of the Northern Hemisphere, with significant diversity in North/South American mountains and Southeast Asia

• The fruits are berries that develop from an inferior ovary and are typically brightly colored (red or blue-purple)

• The genus was first scientifically described by Carl Linnaeus in 1753, with the name possibly derived from the Latin word "bacca" meaning berry

• Modern genetic analyses show Vaccinium is not monophyletic - some Asian species are more closely related to other genera like Agapetes

• Fossil evidence of Vaccinium (V. minutulum seeds) dates back to the Middle Miocene period, found in Poland
Vaccinia.title: Vaccinium

Vibrio vulnificus.facts:
Here are the key facts about Vibrio vulnificus:

• It is a gram-negative, motile, curved rod-shaped bacterium found in marine environments (especially estuaries and coastal areas) and is related to the bacteria that causes cholera

• Infections have increased eightfold in the Eastern United States from 1988-2018, partly due to rising ocean temperatures

• The bacteria can cause severe infections through two main routes: contaminated seafood consumption (especially raw oysters) and wound infections from exposure to contaminated water

• It has a genome size of approximately 5.3 Mbp, organized into two circular chromosomes, making it larger than its relative V. cholerae

• The most dangerous strains have three key features: an anti-phagocytic capsule that protects from immune response, ability to produce harmful toxins, and increased virulence in patients with high iron levels

• The bacteria can become naturally transformable (able to take up DNA) when growing on chitin found in crab shells

• First identified as a source of human disease in 1976

These facts capture the key biological characteristics, medical significance, and recent trends regarding this pathogen.
Vibrio vulnificus.title: Vibrio vulnificus

Viral infectivity.facts:
Here are the key facts about Viral infectivity factor (Vif):

• Vif is an accessory protein found in HIV and other lentiviruses that is essential for viral replication

• Its main function is to neutralize APOBEC (particularly APOBEC3G), a human enzyme that would otherwise mutate and destroy viral genetic material

• HIV-1 Vif works by targeting APOBEC3G for degradation by hijacking the cell's own protein degradation machinery (specifically the Cullin5 E3 Ubiquitin Ligase system)

• Without Vif, APOBEC3G would cause fatal mutations in the viral genome, making it a natural defense mechanism against retroviruses that HIV has evolved to counter

• HIV-1 Vif and HIV-2 Vif are only about 30% identical at the amino acid level and attach to APOBEC proteins in different ways

• Vif can inhibit multiple forms of APOBEC proteins (A3C, A3D, A3F, and A3H) using different binding surfaces

• Recent research has shown that phosphorylation of Vif by host AKT at Thr20 enhances its ability to degrade APOBEC3G and increase HIV infectivity

These facts capture the essential aspects of Vif's role in viral infection and its molecular mechanisms.
Viral infectivity.title: Viral infectivity factor

Virulence.facts:
Here are the key facts about Virulence:

• Virulence is a pathogen's or microorganism's ability to cause damage to its host, measuring the degree of damage caused

• The term comes from the Latin word "virulentus" meaning "poisoned wound" or "full of poison" and applies to all pathogens, not just viruses

• From an ecological perspective, virulence represents the loss of fitness induced by a parasite upon its host

• Virulence factors are specific characteristics (typically proteins or molecules) that enable pathogens to cause disease and can be transferred between organisms via plasmids

• Bacteria use specialized secretion systems to inject virulence factors (effector proteins) into host cells

• Bacterial virulence factors are coded for by genes in chromosomal DNA, bacteriophage DNA, or plasmids

• Bacteria use a communication system called quorum sensing to coordinate the release of virulence factors

• Host response to infection can contribute to pathogenesis, sometimes causing additional damage to host tissues (e.g., cytokine storm)

• Successful bacterial infection often requires adhesion (binding to host cells) and colonization (establishing presence in the host body)
Virulence.title: Virulence

Virulence factor.facts:
Here are the key facts about Virulence Factors:

• Virulence factors are structures, molecules, and regulatory systems that help pathogens (bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa) infect and survive within hosts

• These factors can be either intrinsic (chromosomally encoded) or acquired through mobile genetic elements like plasmids and bacteriophages

• Virulence factors can spread between bacteria through horizontal gene transfer, potentially turning harmless bacteria into dangerous pathogens

• Key functions of virulence factors include:
  - Colonization of host tissue
  - Evasion or suppression of host immune response
  - Cell entry and exit (for intracellular pathogens)
  - Extraction of nutrients from the host

• Bacteria use specific structures for attachment, such as adhesins, lipoteichoic acid, and surface proteins to bind to host tissue

• Bacterial capsules, made of carbohydrates, help protect against the host's immune system by preventing phagocytosis

• Some bacteria produce immunoglobulin proteases that can break down host antibodies, helping them evade immune responses

• Gram-negative bacteria specifically use membrane vesicles to secrete virulence factors at the host-pathogen interface
Virulence factor.title: Virulence factor
